abstract: Gus T Ridgel, one of first black students admitted to University of Missouri in 1950, reflects on fight for racial justice during his time on campus and weighs in on recent incidents there; says he is disappointed in racist sentiment that led to widespread protests, but encouraged by swift and decisive action of demonstrators; protest group had named itself Concerned Students 1950 in reference to year Ridgel entered school.
lead_paragraph: Gus T. Ridgel, one of the first black students admitted to the University of Missouri, said he was surprised and disappointed by the racist incidents that prompted the recent campus upheaval.

headline.main: A Real Missouri ‘Concerned Student 1950’ Speaks, at Age 89
headline.print_headline: A Real Missouri ‘Student 1950’ Speaks, at Age 89

snippet: Gus T. Ridgel, one of the first black students admitted to the University of Missouri, said he was surprised and disappointed by the racist incidents that prompted the recent campus upheaval.
